Can someone explain how the Democratic Committee has the power to disenfranchise a whole state just because that state's Democratic Party chose to move their primary date? What difference does it make to the rest of the states? Why does Iowa get to be first all the time?

 A political party can use whatever method they like to choose a candiate. They can flip a coin or pull a name out of a hat. They could hold just one primary in one state, or try to poll every registered member they can get ahold of. It's entirely their choice, they can make up whatever rules they like.

Clinton shall benefit when she wins the nomination and Michigan folk remember that she did not abandon their state, and that she visited and campaigned there.

 
 No, she did NOT visit and campaign here, only Dennis Kucinich did. She didn't remove her name from the ballot when the others did because it wouldn't have mattered anyway, or so said her campaign spokesman. http://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/10/us/politics/10michigan.html?ref=politics
 
 As a Michigan folk I applaud our state party wanting to give attention to Michigan by moving up our primary, but in effect, by playing a game of chicken with the national DNC and losing, they've disenfranchised us altogether! And that's ###### me off. 
 
 I don't attribute any meaning to Hillary "winning" here.
antonia

I saw a newscast of her campaigning in what one assumed was Michigan since that's what they were describing. But I suppose you are correct, if the New York Times reports that the Clinton campaign states they weren't going to campaign there. (That they didn't.)
 
 The article you link, however, reports a much more Michigan-sympathetic statement from the campaign, IMO, which is also along the lines of what I recall reading (in addition to Mrs. Clinton's expressed desire not to leave the Michigan voters with nothing):
 
 Mrs. Clinton's advisers said it would be foolish to rebuff an important swing state, especially since doing so could alienate Democratic-leaning independents who could be favoring her. But she is also taking a risk that staying in Michigan will not hurt her in Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina. 
 
 And .... it's not her fault Edwards and Obama took their names off. I think that reflects more on them and theri campaigns.
 
 But bottom line, I don't know why the Democratic party went so far with this, when the Republicans didn't. I think it's awful the Democrat Michigan voters were disenfranchised in this manner, especially with the unemployment so high. The Republicans, at least, are allowing some delegates. 
 
 I guess the people of Michigan will have to figure out what they want to do with all that. 
 
 Certainly our scheduling of states could be examined, the way we let some folks play more of an influential role than others. I would be happy to allow Michigan to lead the nation more.
 
 I still wouldn't vote Republican, though. I don't think they can clean up the mess anywhere in the nation. (But that's me!)
